channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: European Gas Prices Jump as Middle East Risk Returns to Market
item.description: European natural gas prices surged after Israel carried out a wave of strikes against Iran, raising fears of a wider war in a region that is key to global energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: A natural gas supply at a district heating plant in Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: FIFA to Splash $1 Billion of Prize Money on First Club World Cup
item.description: FIFA, the global governing body of international soccer, has lured some of the world’s top teams to the US for an inaugural Club World Cup with a record $1 billion to be distributed over the next month.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Cancel, Vanessa Perdomo

media:content.media:description: Manchester City’s Erling Haaland will be among the many stars participating in the inaugural FIFA Club World Cup in the US.

item.title: Bets Emerge That End to Powell’s Term Means More Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: The prospect of a shift in US monetary policy when President Donald Trump replaces Jerome Powell at the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair in May 2026 has interest-rate traders looking for pay dirt.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Thomas Laubach Research Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. Powell said policymakers are weighing changes to key parts of the framework that guides their monetary policy decisions, including how they think about shortfalls in US employment and approach their inflation target.

item.title: Dollar’s Tepid Rebound Reinforces Questions Around Haven Role
item.description: The dollar’s muted rally against major peers after Israel’s strikes on Iran reinforced the impression that the greenback’s role as a global haven is fading.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson, Ruth Carson, Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: Stacks of U.S. $100 bills are arranged for a photograph in New York, U.S., on Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013. The U.S. dollar advanced in trading today to the highest in almost three weeks against a basket of major currencies.

item.title: Stocks Trim Declines With Oil Traders on Edge: Markets Wrap
item.description: Global markets moved into defensive mode after Israeli airstrikes on Iranian nuclear targets sent oil sharply higher. Stocks pared losses, as traders waited for signs of escalation before scaling back risk in a week of encouraging data on inflation and consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Sid Verma

item.title: Israel Shuts Its Biggest Gas Field, Halting Supply to Egypt
item.description: Israel shut down production at its biggest natural gas field after it launched airstrikes against Iran, stopping supplies to import-dependent Egypt and raising concerns about fuel shortages there.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Anna Shiryaevskaya, Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: A view of the platform of the Leviathan natural gas field in the Mediterranean Sea ifrom the Israeli northern coastal beach of Nasholim, on August 29, 2022.

item.title: Rise of Ultra Conservative Tests Rally in Chile Stock Prices
item.description: Investors betting on a swing to the right in Chile’s presidential election this year may get more than they bargained for as an ultra conservative candidate rises in the polls.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Gonzalez

media:content.media:description: Employees work at the Chilean Stock Exchange.

item.title: Germany’s Klingbeil to Support Push to End EU Capital-Markets Impasse
item.description: German Finance Minister and Vice Chancellor Lars Klingbeil said he’ll support a push to try to break a deadlock on a decade-old European Union effort to deepen the bloc’s capital markets.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Rauwald, Isolde MacDonogh

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil, Germany's finance minister, at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Germany's economy is facing a third year without growth as businesses struggle with uncertainty around global trade, according to the Bundesbank.

item.title: Crypto Altcoins Lead Slide as Geopolitics Spurs Haven Demand
item.description: Smaller, less liquid tokens such as Solana and Cardano led a decline in cryptocurrencies as financial markets shifted toward safety after Israeli airstrikes on Iranian nuclear targets.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh, Kirk Ogunrinde

item.title: Travel Stocks Sink, Energy Shares Soar as Israel Strikes Iran
item.description: Israel’s strikes on Iran rippled through the US stock market on Friday, sinking shares of travel companies and lifting energy and defense stocks as traders braced for the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin, Peyton Forte, Geoffrey Morgan

item.title: Oil Spikes as Israel’s Attacks on Iran Stoke Fears of Wider War
item.description: Oil surged as much as 14% after Israel carried out airstrikes against Iran, raising fears of a wider war in a region that accounts for a third of global crude production.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Mia Gindis

item.title: Nine Random Friday Thoughts from Joe and Tracy
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from a location allegedly targeted in Israel's wave of strikes on Tehran, Iran, on early morning of June 13, 2025. (Photo by SAN / Middle East Images via AFP) (Photo by SAN/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: SAN/AFP

item.title: Could Iran Close the Strait of Hormuz?
item.description: Oil prices spiked after Israel attacked Iran to degrade its nuclear capabilities. Where the market goes from here will depend on how Iran responds. The most extreme scenario is that the regime escalates by attempting to shut the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway at the mouth of the Persian Gulf. Bloomberg's Will Kennedy reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Pre-IPO Marketplace Hiive Eyes Funding as Competition Rises
item.description: Hiive Markets Ltd., an online trading platform for shares of venture-backed companies, is hoping to raise as much as $100 million as soon as this year, its chief executive officer said.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: The skyline of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024. Vancouver is at the forefront of “harm reduction” policies, those aimed at reducing drugs’ dangers without moral judgments or demands that users quit.

item.title: The Race to Zero in ETF Fees
item.description: According to the latest research from Bloomberg Intelligence, there could be a big sea change if the race to lower ETF fees is over. Athanasios Psarofagis has more on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ford Hit by Rare Earth Shortage
item.description: Ford CEO Jim Farley says his company is struggling to secure rare earth materials that are necessary to making cars. He spoke to Bloomberg's Matt Miller in Le Mans, France. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Soybean Oil Surges With Trump Plan to Boost US Biofuel Quotas
item.description: Soybean oil rallied on the Trump administration’s proposal allowing oil refiners to blend more biofuels into gasoline and diesel next year.
item.dc:creator: Erin Ailworth

item.title: Ex-Columbia Student Seeks Release After US Misses Deadline
item.description: Lawyers for a former Columbia University graduate student who participated in pro-Palestinian protests asked a US judge to release him after the government failed to file an appeal by a Friday deadline.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil Photographer: Selcuk Acar/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Egypt Cuts Gas Supply to Some Factories After Israeli Flows Dip
item.description: Egypt cut natural gas supplies to some industries after flows from Israel fell, raising the prospects of shortages returning to the North African country.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: A Liquefied Natural Gas tanker sails through the Suez Canal near Ismailia, Egypt.

item.title: Trump Plans Biofuel Quota Boost, Seeks to Crimp Imports
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing oil refiners blend more biofuels into gasoline and diesel next year while seeking to discourage the use of imported supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kim Chipman

media:content.media:description: A Phillips 66 renewable fuels refinery in Rodeo, California.

item.title: US Sentiment Rises as Inflation Expectations Improve
item.description: US consumer sentiment rose 8.3 points to 60.5 in June, according to the University of Michigan. The figure easily topped all expectations in a Bloomberg survey of economists. Mike McKee reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: S&P 500’s Weekly Gains in Jeopardy After Israel Attacks Iran
item.description: The US stock market was on track to finish flat for the week as oil prices surged and traders sought safety in bonds after Israel attacked Iran’s capital following an escalation of tensions over the country’s rapidly advancing nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: First-responders outside a building that was hit by an Israeli strike in Tehran, on June 13.

item.title: Gold Jumps After Israel Launches Strikes on Iran’s Nuclear Sites
item.description: Gold spiked after Israel conducted airstrikes targeting Iran’s nuclear sites and military leadership, raising fears that hostilities between the two nations may spiral into a wider regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Gold paused its record-breaking rally amid optimism over US-Japan trade talks, after bullion earlier reached another all-time high. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: CATL Shares Clouded by Bleak Outlook After Mega Hong Kong Debut
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. has received little love following its splashy $5.2 billion listing in Hong Kong last month, as investors eye multifold challenges in the global EV battery market.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Robin Zeng, founder and chairman of CATL, left, with Paul Chan, Hong Kong's financial secretary, during the company's listing ceremony in Hong Kong on May 20. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: ESR Shareholders Approve $7 Billion Buyout By Investor Group
item.description: Shareholders of ESR Group Ltd. approved a buyout deal by a consortium of investors valuing the Hong Kong-listed warehouse operator at about $7 billion via a scheme of arrangement.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Manuel Baigorri

media:content.media:description: Illuminated office buildings in the Central district in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023. In a bad year for deals globally, the value of mergers and acquisitions in mainland China and Hong Kong has fallen 6% to about $185 billion, Bloomberg-compiled data show. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Says He Sees ‘No Obstacles’ to UK-US Trade Deal
item.description: “We’re in the final stages of implementing now,” UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer says when asked about the progress of the UK’s trade deal with the US. “We haven’t got any hiccups or obstacles.” He made the comments during an interview with Bloomberg’s Mishal Husain at 10 Downing Street.

item.title: Dundee Precious to Buy Adriatic Metals for $1.25 Billion
item.description: Dundee Precious Metals Inc. agreed to buy Adriatic Metals Plc, which operates a silver project in Bosnia and Herzegovina, for about $1.25 billion, as miners respond to surging precious metal prices.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Biesheuvel, Dylan Griffiths

media:content.media:description: Adriatic Metals Source: Adriatic Metals Plc

item.title: Adobe Is Not an ‘AI Loser,’ D.A. Davidson’s Luria Says
item.description: Gil Luria, D.A. Davidson managing director, says AI will be accretive to Adobe’s earnings on the June 12 episode of “Bloomberg The Close.” Adobe said sales will be about $5.88 billion to $5.93 billion in the period ending in August.

item.title: Meat Giant JBS Eyes Deeper Pockets as It Starts New York Trading
item.description: JBS NV shares started trading in New York, giving the world’s largest meat producer a market value of about $15 billion as it culminated a years-long effort to reach a broader pool of investors.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: The JBS Greeley meatpacking facility in Greeley, Colorado.

item.title: Israel Strike on Iran Sparks Risk Off Sentiment; Iran Retaliates | Bloomberg Brief 6/13/2025
item.description: Oil spikes and stocks sell off after Israel launched a broad offensive on Iranian military and nuclear targets overnight. Iran retaliates and blames the US for Israel's attack, while the US denies any involvement. Nadia Martin Wiggen of Svelland Capital sees further gains in crude prices amid risks of escalation in the conflict. Thomas Wagner of Knighthead Capital Management, speaking at Le Mans, says the Fed needs to cut given inflation is below target and concerns over growth persist. (Source: Bloomberg)
